results.title: The Man who thought with his hat (K)
results.brief_description: The amusing, satirical story of Alec Noll, President of Agonia. He was such an important man, but with one strange characteristic…he thought with his hat. Based on a book by Swedish writer, Gunnar Berefelt.

results.title: The Man who stops accidents
results.creator_credit: Denis Ward and Technical and Scientific Films
results.brief_description: Although most managements take precautions to prevent foreseeable accidents, they are still common, a very large percentage being caused by personal carelessness. In this film, the duties of the foreman in accident prevention are stressed. It goes on to show a series of “typical” accidents and “puts the clock back” on them to show how they could have been prevented.

results.title: The Man who stole Uganda
results.creator_credit: John Sheppard and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Uganda’s General Milton Obote was deposed by his own army. It took Major General Idi Amin, self-appointed Head of Army and State, just one week to take charge of key services and installations. Behind this well-organised takeover lies a history of military corruption.

results.title: The Man who skied Antarctica
results.brief_description: Yuichiro Miura, the man who skied down Everest, seeks self-discovery on an Antarctic peak where he encounters storm, crevasse and avalanche. A gripping metaphor of challenge and supreme human perseverance.
results.description: Yuichiro Miura, the man who skied down Everest, seeks self-discovery on an Antarctic peak where he encounters storm, crevasse and avalanche. A gripping metaphor of challenge and supreme human perseverance.

results.title: The Man who shot Liberty Valance
results.creator_credit: John Ford, Willis Goldbeck and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: John Ford’s autumnal western is a surprisingly dark study of the limitations of the masculine values that have underpinned his oeuvre of western film. James Stewart plays an Eastern lawyer, Ransom Stottard, who arrives in a small western town determined to espouse the rule of law not the rule of the gun. But the town is being menaced by a sadistic mob of bandits, led by Liberty Valance (Lee Marvin), who are being bankrolled by rich cattle merchants who are opposed to statehood and any ensuing limitations to their claim for land. Stottard’s belief in the calm rules of his legal profession is opposed to Tom Doniphon’s (John Wayne) belief that only a gun can stop Liberty’s harassment of the townspeople. Culminating in a breathtaking shoot-out at night, “The Man who shot Liberty Valance” stands as one of Ford’s most eloquent films, one in which the rugged individualist ethos that he celebrated in “Stagecoach” and “She wore a yellow ribbon” are shown to be in perpetual conflict with the democratic demands of nationhood. The performances by Wayne and Stewart are amongst those performers’ best, and they are ably supported by Vera Miles, Strother Martin (in one of the few African-American representations depicted in the classical Western genre), Lee Marvin, and in a small but cruelly effective role, by Lee Van Cleef
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Ford, Willis Goldbeck and Paramount Pictures

results.title: The Man who planted trees (K)
results.creator_credit: Frederic Back, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Radio Canada
results.brief_description: Another award winning title by Frederic Back, creator of the prize winning animated film CRAC, who is showcased in this new half hour film which pays tribute to a man whose toil and dedication brought life to a barren, desolate region high in the French Alps. A triumphant testament to one man’s indomitable spirit. “The Man Who Planted Trees” is a thought provoking tale, a visually stunning tour de force, from a genius in the fine art of animated cinema. Winner of more than 25 awards, including Academy Award, 1988. Narrated by Christopher Plummer and based on a story by Jean Giono.

results.title: The Man Who Named the World/Declaration of a Heretic
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visionaries”.
“The Man who named the World” - Professor James Lovelock is responsible for one of the most revolutionary environmental ideas - the Gaia hypothesis. This says that the planet is more than a cosmic sphere brimming with life, it is a single organism that has been alive for three and a half billion years. “Declaration of a Heretic” - Jeremy Rivkin is a professional activist. For many years his Foundation on Economic Trends has challenged the bio sciences in the court rooms. He was responsible for preventing the release of genetically engineered bacteria onto Californian strawberry crops, he’s putting the brakes on the Human Genome Project, and he’s forced the genetic engineers to conduct their experiments in an atmosphere of public scrutiny. Rated: G

results.title: The Man who loves frogs: Mike Tyler
results.brief_description: One man’s look at the enormous variety of frog species found in Australia, the differences between them, and the ways each has adapted to its own particular lifestyle/environment.

results.title: The Man who loved machines
results.creator_credit: Sidney Goldsmith, David Verrall and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A humorous, animated science film that introduces students to the nature of energy and energy conservation, as well as to the second law of thermodynamics, entropy. The points are underscored by the observations of an all-seeing dog in need of a doghouse, whose master, though obsessed with machines, is finally convinced that the simplest tool is sometimes the most energy-efficient! Voice and Narration by Terrence Labrosse. Music by Peter Mendieta.
